repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Rural Education Project in Support
            of the First Phase of the Rural Education Program

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Rural Education Project
            in Support of the First Phase of the Rural Education Program
            for Peru were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            this project was designed as the first phase of an Adaptable
            Program Loans (APLs). APLs support a long term vision and
            depend on the compliance of agreed triggers linked to the
            medium term sector policies. This instrument is relevant
            when institutions are strong and have a track record of
            consistency for a period of time that goes beyond that
            expected for the project itself. While this project was
            designed during a period when the Ministry of Education had
            shown continuity in its policies, the frequent changes in
            Ministers and the subsequent changes in vision were not
            foreseen. Thus, this type of lending instrument was not
            appropriate for such a highly uncertain context where the
            continuity of the sector policy framework was not in place.
            In such cases, selecting a sector investment loan might have
            been more effective. Political support is linked to
            decision-making about human and financial resources
            allocation to ensure adequate implementation of a project.
            In the case of this project, the frequent changes in
            ministers (there were six different Ministers, whose average
            tenure, was about one year) and the consequent changes of
            Directors and Project Managers, resulted in reduced
            ownership of the project and changes in priorities. As a
            result, the higher levels of the Ministry did not prioritize
            the project and human resource allocation weakened with
            time. Even though the Bank team discussed the project with
            all new incoming teams, the vision of improving rural
            education was lost for other priorities brought by the new
            administrations. Thus, political risk is critical for
            project implementation.

5086750.trustfund:
TF026867-PHRD-PERU: RURAL EDUCATION AND
            TEACHER DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF025935-PHRD-RURAL EDUCATION &
            TEACHER DEV. PROJ. (BANK-EXECUTED),TF025902-PHRD-RURAL EDUCATION &
            TEACHER DEV. PROJECT(RECIPIENT-EXEC.)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rural Education Project in Peru will
            support the Government's strategy for improving the
            quality, and equity of basic education, through investments
            in rural areas with the lowest education indicators, and
            through systemic reforms of teacher policy, and education
            management. The project components are as follows. The first
            component will increase access to, and quality of initial,
            pre-school, and secondary education for children in rural
            areas. Initial, and pre-school education will have a
            non-formal approach to education, focused not only on
            children, but on parents and siblings within a family, and
            community framework. Trained community educators, fluent in
            the local languages will provide initial education, and,
            interventions combining formal, and non-formal approaches
            will follow for pre-school, which includes the introduction
            to the Spanish language. Distance secondary education will
            be developed (in addition to traditional school delivery)
            through cost-effective information and communication
            technologies, and teacher training assistance. The second
            component focuses on the quality of teaching, and learning
            in primary schools in the targeted rural areas, supporting
            continuous professional development focused on rural
            teachers, developing, and distributing multi-grade, and
            bilingual instruction materials, and, rehabilitating
            classrooms. The third component will support the reform of
            teacher policy, and education management, motivating
            linkages towards educational standards, by supporting
            schools development, within the national assessment system,
            through strategic analysis and policy research.

repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Rural Education and Teacher
            Development Project : indigenous peoples plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This Indigenous Peoples Plan (IPP)
            examines the ethnic and cultural context of the Peruvian
            nation, where more than a third of its population belongs to
            indigenous nations, mostly Quechua and Aymara living in the
            Andean region, and, additionally, in the Peruvian Amazon
            forest (which covers 62 percent of the territory) forty two
            ethno-linguistic groups live, with their own economic and
            political characteristics. Following a review of the
            country's legal framework, which specifies the rights
            of indigenous people as included in the Constitution, the
            General Education Act, the Primary Education Regulations,
            and recent regulations created by the National
            Inter-Cultural Bilingual Education Directorate, measures are
            hereby identified, specifically on inter-cultural bilingual
            education. Teaching materials for inter-cultural bilingual
            education are a substantive component of the strategy, and,
            student education materials will be distributed, including
            textbooks for language and mathematics. Alternative
            materials for multi-grade, and single teacher classrooms
            will also be prepared, as will educational modules for
            preschool education from a self-paced perspective, using
            indigenous languages as primary, with Spanish as secondary
            language. Participatory approaches will involve regional
            teams, including indigenous peoples, whose dynamic should
            facilitate the internal, and external review processes.
            Validation and completion of textbook production, will be
            followed by adjustments, and reprinting as needed. Classroom
            libraries will be gradually established for early childhood
            bilingual education, in three languages: Quechua, Aymara,
            and Aguaruna, and, by 2005 in three additional languages:
            Shipibo, Chayahuita, and Ashaninka. A curriculum proposal
            will be prepared, and introduced related to the needs, and
            demands as identified during consultations among bilingual
            people, followed by due progress in introducing bilingual
            study programs.
